div.p:
In this module, we will
discuss best practices

for translating your baseline
and benchmarking datasets

into clear, metric-based
sustainability goals.

From there, your team
will be well informed

to select and implement
sustainability measures
that meet your facility's specific needs

and provide opportunities
for continuous improvement.

The slides that follow
will explain methods

for analyzing data and
setting sustainability goals,

evaluating different
sustainability measures,

and developing a
sustainability action plan.
The data produced by benchmarking
will provide your team with information
to formulate operational performance plans

for each of the four
fundamentals individually
and in combination.

As a next step, analyze
the benchmarking data

to determine trends in
resource consumption

and to estimate the
potential for improvements.

Benchmarking data can be
used to rank facilities

by performance in
different compliance areas,
identify high-performing facilities
for replicable practices,
prioritize poor-performing facilities
for immediate improvement,

and identify opportunities
to save resources and costs.
Within Portfolio Manager it is possible

to generate progress reports
on individual facilities
and entire portfolios.

The value of benchmarking
data becomes apparent

once it's analyzed for resource
use patterns and trends.
Your team will need to determine
which combination of analysis methods
best fit your facility's needs.
Analyzing quantitative data

will allow you to compare
consumption and cost data

across utilities over time
and will reveal trends.
This knowledge is critical

to incorporate into strategic
planning and action.

Use profiles to identify
energy consumption

peaks and valleys, and to
determine how they relate
to operations or key events.
Performance comparisons:

Compare the use and performance
data of similar facilities

within your campus or
across your department.
Financial impact assessments:
Identify areas of high-cost resource use.

Analyzing qualitative
data will review feedback
from building occupants
and incorporate preferences and behaviors

into sustainable organizational
values and procedures.
This will influence outcomes
and reveal sustainability choices.
It will also enable continual improvement
and ensure adaptive management.

Interviews can be used
to document opinions,

experiences, and best
practices from building staff,

occupants, and others about
how building systems are used.
Policies and procedure reviews

examine how organizational
policies and operating procedures

positively or negatively
impact resource use.
How do you set sustainability goals?

The best way is to start with
accurate benchmarking data.

With accurate data,
the sustainability team
can set actionable performance goals

that take into account
benchmarking results,
federal requirements and mandates,

departmental strategic
sustainability goals,
facility priorities based on the results
from technical assessments and audits,

and performance goals
of similar facilities.
It is helpful to create

a table of sustainability
performance goals

in order to have one list
incorporating all potential goals.

This table will make it
easier to share progress

and status updates with
external stakeholders.
To set meaningful goals with buy-in,

now is a good time to
actively engage the team.
Schedule a series of meetings

to review data analysis results,
discuss performance gaps,
and brainstorm improvement strategies.
First, establish a vision statement

to articulate exactly how
sustainability helps the facility
and department meet its mission.

Next, develop a set of
sustainability priorities

to identify specific focus
areas or high-priority items
that are unique to your site.
Finally, link performance goals
to priorities with clear metrics
that correspond to each priority.
When you establish a clear vision,

your objectives should naturally
flow out of this vision,

then your criteria emerge
from those objectives.

Next, you can benchmark
against that criteria.

And finally, you can establish
methods to track results.

Work with your team to
develop effective strategies
and track progress using SMART goals

that are specific, measurable
and monitored, achievable,
realistic, and time-bound.

Common ways to express
sustainability goals

include defined reduction
where goals expressed

in terms of a specific
quantity or percentage decrease

such as a 10% water reduction
or an annual energy reduction
of 300 kilowatt hours;
best-in-class, where goals are expressed
as a certain level of performance
compared to an established benchmark;

efficiency improvement
where goals are expressed

as a function of reducing
the resource use intensity
of a specific performance indicator;

environmental improvement
where goals are translated

as savings presented in
pollution prevention targets
or materials avoidance units.

Additionally, your
facility may find it useful

to establish threshold goals
where goals are expressed

as a minimum acceptable
level of performance

and stretch goals where
goals are expressed
as levels beyond typical targets

to create an incentive
for greater achievement.
With performance goals firmly established,

your team can now
develop an integrated set
of sustainability measures.

Sustainability measures
can include projects,
policies, and procedures.

In many cases, your team will
want to strategically combine

several sustainability
measures to achieve a goal.

Take advantage up front
of the low-hanging fruit,

or no-cost, low-cost
measures, such as repairs

and scheduled preventative
maintenance to building systems;

policy revisions to
operations and maintenance;

purchasing and property
management policies;

or efficiency upgrades for
lighting and water fixtures.
Occupant behavior changes are another way

to improve the sustainability
of your facility.

Building occupants'
behavior has been shown

to directly impact up to 30%
of facility resource use.

Include sustainability measures
that strategically target

the behavior of building
users and operators.

Training for building operators
including property managers,

O&M staff, and cleaning
crew can have big payoffs.

Educating occupants about
resource consumption
can yield big savings.

Examples of beneficial behavior
include turning off lights
and shared technology when not in use,

using double-sided printing
options throughout the building,

reducing plug loads by unplugging
equipment at the strip,

taking stairs for short
trips between floors,
using water from the tap or water cooler
instead of bottled water,
and ride sharing or using public transit.
After exploring low-hanging fruit
and occupant behavior changes,

consider integrating
sustainability measures
into capital improvement projects.

Ensure that all equipment
is tuned up, commissioned,
calibrated, and operating efficiently.

Assess current needs and right
size replacement equipment;

specify the most energy-efficient
components and models
when replacing equipment;

and integrate sustainability
design features
into the project

such as performance-oriented
siding and landscaping,

day lighting, recycled content,
design for disassembly,
and passive heating and cooling.

Measures that are life
cycle cost-effective

have estimated savings that
exceed the estimated cost
over their lifespan.
In economic terms, a building design

is deemed to be cost
effective if it results

in benefits equal to
those of alternate designs

and has a lower whole-life cost
or total cost of ownership.
For your team's first project,
it is important to identify simple actions

that could be made to show
quick progress or payback.

Let's explore some
energy-efficiency measures
that can lead to a more sustainable
and enjoyable office environment.

One example is to align
daylight harvesting
with space function to reduce the need

for electric lighting, and
heating and cooling loads.

There are several ways to
implement this measure.
For example, by installing light shelves

to increase reflectivity
at window openings
to increase daylight penetration.
Running light tubes through ceilings

to supply more natural
light from the roof.

Installing window
shadings and glare filters
to reduce glare on workstations.

Lowering workstation walls to
one meter to provide privacy

while transmitting light
across office space.
Maximizing access to outdoor views

and light to increase
the occupant comfort,
satisfaction, and productivity
and providing controls for window shades
to empower occupants to manage the glare
and heat emitted into the workspace.
HVAC systems typically comprise
the largest energy-using component
of any building or facility,

and have the greatest
energy savings opportunity.

In new buildings, design
buildings to site HVAC systems
towards the center of the building
to keep conditioned air near workspaces
and avoid loss through exterior walls.

In existing buildings, look
for component replacements

to optimize performance
of the overall system.

Actions that can be taken to
capitalize on this opportunity

include upgrading insulation,
building envelope sealants,
and windows to downsize the HVAC system
and lower energy consumption.

Increasing ventilation rates
to replace contaminated air
with filtered air from the outdoors

to improve work performance
and occupant health.

Taking advantage of
opportunities to re-commission
or retro-commission HVAC systems to ensure

they are operating using
ASHRAE-90.1 recommended settings,
and where possible display HVAC

and other resource-using
system information

in common areas to educate
building occupants.
Water efficiency measures are another way

of improving the
sustainability of a facility.

Rainwater harvesting
systems capture and reuse
non-potable, onsite water,
that can be used for landscape irrigation

and reduce potable water and
non-potable water consumption.

This measure presents
the following benefits
related to improved sustainability.
Green roofs substantially reduce heat loss
through the roof membrane.

Stormwater collection
and retention systems

reduce the energy required
to pump and process water
at the municipal level.

Wetland plant species
can enhance water quality
through bio-digestion of pollutants.
For health reasons,

gray water and storm
water harvesting systems
must comply with local building codes.
Restrooms present opportunities

to improve the water
efficiency of a facility.
Here are some measures to consider

when looking to improve the
water efficiency of restrooms.

Implement a fixture
replacement and retrofit policy

with technologically advanced
water-efficient alternatives
to conventional fixtures.
Use waterless urinals where appropriate

and convert faucets to automated
and sensor-driven fixtures
for greater efficiency.
Use condensate from the HVAC unit
as a non-potable water source
for flushing toilets and urinals.

Set up a leak detection
program to provide occupants
an easy way to report leaks.

The benefits of implementing
sustainability measures

in restrooms includes
automated electric hand dryers
to eliminate the need for paper products,
waste heat from HVAC systems can be used

to preheat domestic hot water;
automated sensor faucets

limit the passing of germs
from occupant to occupant.
Selecting the right renovation materials

can help contribute to a
more sustainable operation.

Procure durable,
environmentally-preferable,
and long-lasting materials
specified from local suppliers and vendors
when undergoing a major renovation.
Actions related to this efficiency measure

include selecting
locally sourced materials
that require less transportation

and support local economies,
specify low-emitting materials
to create healthy indoor air quality.

Composting organic
waste is another measure

for improving the operational
sustainability of a facility.
Composting appropriately eliminates waste
and reuses natural materials

as nutrients for useful
landscaping purposes.
The benefits associated with composting

are improved water retention,
which leads to a reduced need
for irrigation on gardens and grounds,
and energy and water savings
resulting from reducing portable water use
for garbage disposal.

The use of environmentally-friendly
cleaning products
within a facility

contributes to a healthier
indoor environment.

Facilities should establish
a green cleaning policy

for the purchase and use
of nontoxic, low or no-VOC

and biobased cleaning
equipment and materials.

Biobased products are commercial
or industrial products

that are significantly composed
of biological products,

renewable agricultural materials
including plant, animal,

and marine materials,
or forestry materials.
Green cleaning products used in restrooms
and food preparation areas

keep toxins from entering
the facility's water
and sewer discharge.
Non-toxic and biobased cleaning products

provide a save and
healthy work environment.

An example of an indoor
environmental quality measure
is the use of indoor plants.
Indoor plants can improve air quality,
create more comfortable spaces,
and improve workplace satisfaction.

Plants can filter air, sequester
carbon, produce oxygen,

and absorb chemicals such
as benzine, formaldehyde,
or trichloroethylene.

Consider green walls
to great inspirational

or contemplative interior
spaces, humidify the air,
and improve indoor air quality.
Interior acoustics can play a big role

in improving the indoor
environmental quality
of an office.

Good interior acoustics
are particularly important
to employees working in open spaces.
Acoustic interior panels

made of environmentally-preferable
materials

are a great option for
reducing noise levels

without affecting the indoor
environmental quality.

Acoustic interior panels
made of translucent material

block sound while allowing
daylight or general light
to penetrate into a space,

which can lessen the need
for electric lighting.
Actions for improving interior acoustics
include using materials

such as acoustic ceiling tiles
and carpeting to absorb sound,

and using sound blocking
strategies such as space design

and furniture placement to
control noise-generating sources.
The sustainability action plan is critical

to cement your facility's
commitment to sustainability
and to maintain important momentum.
The best practices

for developing a
sustainability action plan
include asking senior management
to host an official launch event,
establishing clear roles for team members,
ensuring project expectations

mesh with team members'
availability and duties,

keeping team members
consistently up to date

and seeking their input,
scheduling regular check-ins,
and setting achievable timelines
for deliverables and checkpoints.

Summarizing, benchmark
and goal setting results

in an action plan documents
your team's progress

and presents it effectively
to management, staff,
or other audiences.

Consider updating your
action plan annually.

Ensure your action plan
covers the critical elements

like sustainability program
intent, sustainability vision,
priorities and performance goals,

and current benchmarking results
relative to the baseline.
Include technical steps and targets
related to each performance goal

such as sustainability
measures that specify actions
and policies for meeting each goal,

key performance metrics
that identify units used

for tracking progress, an
implementation timeline

that details a timeframe for
carrying out each measure,

team roles and resources
relating to each measure,
and outreach and communication plans

to influence occupant
behavior and garner support.

Also, include a measurement
and reporting schedule
to document progress.

In module four, we reviewed
benchmarking and analyzing data
to set sustainability goals,

selecting and evaluating
sustainability measures,

and developing a
sustainability action plan.
In the next module,

we will discuss the
importance of sustainability
as a cycle for continuous improvement.
